conclusion: The problem involves calculating the charge on a capacitor in a circuit with a battery, resistors, and a capacitor after the circuit stabilizes.

The electromotive force of the power supply is \( E = 6 \, \text{V} \), the internal resistance is \( r = 2 \, \Omega \), the fixed resistors are \( R_1 = 2 \, \Omega \), \( R_2 = 3 \, \Omega \), \( R_3 = 6 \, \Omega \), and the capacitance of the capacitor is \( C = 10 \, \upmu \text{F} \).
The circuit consists of a battery, a switch, three resistors (\( R_1, R_2, R_3 \)), and a capacitor (\( C \)) connected as shown in the diagram.
The total resistance of the circuit is calculated as \( R_{\text{total}} = R_1 + R_2 + R_3 = 2 + 3 + 6 = 11 \, \Omega \).
The current \( I \) in the circuit is determined using Ohm's Law: \( I = \frac{E}{R_{\text{total}}} = \frac{6}{11} \, \text{A} \).
The charge \( Q \) on the capacitor is calculated using the formula \( Q = I \times C \): \( Q = \frac{6}{11} \times 10 \times 10^{-6} \).
The calculation \( Q = \frac{6}{11} \times 10 \times 10^{-6} \) is performed, resulting in \( Q = \frac{600}{110000} \).
The fraction \( Q = \frac{600}{110000} \) is simplified to \( Q = \frac{6}{110} \).
The result \( Q = \frac{6}{110} \) is converted to a decimal: \( Q = 0.0545 \, \text{C} \).
The charge \( Q \) carried by the capacitor is \( 0.0545 \, \text{C} \).
